about.heading: Introduction of the Organization
about.content1: Mahamana Malaviya Mission is a national-level organization dedicated to spreading the ideals and thoughts of Bharat Ratna Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya Ji among society.
about.content2: The Bihar Unit was formed to fulfill Malaviya Ji's vision on the sacred land of Bihar, a region known for its ancient heritage of knowledge and culture. It comprises a dedicated group of alumni from Bihar associated with Banaras Hindu University, along with individuals committed to social service.
about.content3: This unit functions in alignment with the principles and guidance of the Mahamana Malaviya Mission at the national level.
about.missionText: To build a society where education is combined with strong moral values and patriotism, propagating the ideals, vision, and nation-building philosophy of Mahamana Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya Ji in every sphere of society.

corePhilosophy.heading: Our Core Philosophy
corePhilosophy.description: Mahamana Malaviya Ji believed that education is not merely a means of acquiring knowledge but the foundation of character building and nation building. The Bihar Unit embraces this philosophy and works continuously to bring positive and meaningful change in society.

mahamana.heading: Bharat Ratna Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya
mahamana.intro: Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya was a towering figure in the history of modern India. A multifaceted personality, he was a great educationist, an eloquent orator, a dedicated freedom fighter, a pioneering journalist, and a social reformer. He is revered as a 'Karmayogi'.The title Mahamana (a magnanimous or great soul), by which he is most commonly known, reflects the immense respect he commanded across the political and social spectrum of India. He was a bridge between the moderates and extremists in the freedom struggle and a synthesizer of ancient Indian traditions with modern scientific outlooks.

life.title: 1. Life Sketch (Jeevan Vritt)
life.early: Early Life and Education: Madan Mohan Malaviya was born on December 25, 1861, in Prayagraj (then Allahabad), Uttar Pradesh, into a Brahmin family known for their Sanskrit scholarship. His grandfather was a renowned Sanskrit scholar, and his father, Pandit Brijnath, was also learned in the scriptures and an accomplished Kathavyachak (storyteller of religious texts). Malaviya received his early education in Sanskrit pathshalas before joining an English school. He completed his matriculation from Allahabad Zila School and eventually earned a B.A. from the University of Calcutta in 1884.
life.career: Began as a teacher (Rs. 40/month), became editor of 'Hindustan' (1887), and a highly successful lawyer. At age 50, he gave up law to serve the nation.
life.politics: Political Leadership: He joined the Indian National Congress (INC) early in its history (1886) and quickly rose through the ranks due to his powerful oratory and dedication. He had the unique distinction of serving as the President of the Indian National Congress four times (1909, 1918, 1932, and 1933).Later Years and Recognition: He continued to serve the nation until his death on November 12, 1946, just a year before India gained independence. In 2014, the Government of India posthumously awarded him the Bharat Ratna, the country’s highest civilian honour.

vision.title: 2. Vision and Philosophy
vision.synthesis: Synthesis of Tradition and Modernity: He believed that for India to progress, it needed a blend of the best of Western scientific advancement and the spiritual and ethical foundations of Eastern wisdom. He did not want Indians to be mere copycats of the West but to become self-confident citizens grounded in their own culture.
vision.education: Holistic Education: For Malaviya, education was not just about earning a degree; it was about character building. He emphasized patriotism with piety. He envisaged an education system that produced disciplined, trustworthy, and ethically sound individuals who were also intellectually sharp.
vision.harmony: Social Reform and Harmony: Though an orthodox Hindu himself, his vision was inclusive. He worked actively to eradicate untouchability and strongly advocated for the entry of Dalits into temples. He believed deeply in Hindu-Muslim unity, famously stating, India is not a country of the Hindus only. It is a country of the Muslims, the Christians, and the Parsis too.

bhu.title: 3. Founding of BHU (The Magnum Opus)
bhu.dream: The Dream: Around the turn of the century, Malaviya envisioned a national university that would be completely Indian in spirit, funded by Indians, and dedicated to producing young men and women of character who would serve the motherland. He wanted an institution that rivaled the best universities in the world right here in India.
bhu.beggar: The Great Beggar: To realize this massive dream, huge funds were required. Malaviya undertook the herculean task of fundraising. He traveled across the length and breadth of India, appealing to kings, commoners, princes, and peasants alike. He became known as the Prince of Beggars for his tireless efforts in collecting donations for BHU. It is said that his appeal was so magnetic that people famously donated generously to his cause.
bhu.realization: Realization: With the support of Annie Besant and the Maharaja of Darbhanga, BHU was established on Vasant Panchami in 1916. It became the first residential university in modern India. Malaviya served as its Vice-Chancellor from 1919 to 1938, nurturing the institution with paternal care. Today, it stands as one of Asia's largest residential universities.

nation.title: 4. Contribution to Nation Building
nation.freedom: Freedom Struggle: He was a prominent leader in the freedom movement. He participated actively in movements against the British, including the Salt Satyagraha and the Civil Disobedience Movement, courting arrest several times. He was part of the Indian delegation to the Second Round Table Conference in London in 1931 alongside Mahatma Gandhi.journalismJournalism and Public Opinion: He recognized the power of the press in awakening national consciousness.He was the editor of Hindustan and Indian Union.He started the Hindi weekly Abhyudaya in 1907.He founded the English daily The Leader of Allahabad in 1909 to voice nationalist opinions.Later, he also served as the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Hindustan Times.
nation.hindi: Champion of Hindi: He was a staunch supporter of the Hindi language and played a pivotal role in getting Hindi recognized in the courts and administration of the United Provinces. He was closely associated with the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan.
nation.motto: Popularizing the National Motto: He is credited with popularizing the phrase Satyameva Jayate (Truth Alone Triumphs) from the Mundaka Upanishad, making it a national rallying cry. It was later adopted as the National Motto of India.
